channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @AberdeenAsher @NotWoofers Aren‚Äôt most ‚Äòexport model‚Äô items only manufactured on demand (after any necessary re-tooling or design changes are made for the receiving military)? I believe the current focus is to generally provide equipment and weapons that are now actually in stock and combat-ready.
@PoliticsAndEd (tangential) Crazy thing: those drums on the flatbed almost came unscathed. Imagine being the driver of this kind of truck in an accident!

@dave_luce @gordon_struth @urbanthoughts11 It‚Äôs not a urban stadium, but compare and contrast how even this parking-heavy example approaches land use and pedestrian / cycling connections compared to most of the American locations cited: https://t.co/eXdXlSC6sG

@dave_luce @gordon_struth @urbanthoughts11 They buried much of the parking for Soldier Field twenty years ago, but it‚Äôs certainly not what I‚Äôd call ‚Äòwalkable‚Äô (unless your yacht is berthed in the nearby marina, that is): https://t.co/frtFYIwxj2
@dave_luce @gordon_struth @urbanthoughts11 Here‚Äôs a better one of Seattle for you: https://t.co/qqNW74bwZF

@dancaroselli These have been popping up in cities nationwide after building code changes in the last decade allowed quick approval of fully wood-frame construction for 4-6 story buildings. Density for cheap! (* the actual allowed number of stories depends on a number of factors, as I recall)

@jmcevoy_2 That quote doesn‚Äôt seem to support a claim of potential ‚Äúkidnap or murder‚Äù. At one point ‚Äúgrabbing him‚Äù is mentioned, but freeing him from extrajudicial extradition is hardly kidnapping. The ‚Äúshooting‚Äù is in reference disabling aircraft tires, not people. What am I missing?
@markproxy Agreeing that we have a problem (as well as agreeing how serious that problem is) is a first step that we haven‚Äôt quite yet completed.
@JPutanero @TrentTelenko No one is getting a promotion* for devoting time and money to upgrading their HVAC system. (* in most current corporate cultures)

@DougCarlisle @TrentTelenko This is where mesh networks shine! In reality, though, if you can get a clear signal when the container is loaded/unloaded by a crane, couldn‚Äôt tracking automatically just switch to following the ship? Power-save when stationary (i.e. in a yard) or in the dark?

@Behrooz60 @Aintropy @PhillipsPOBrien Sonic triangulation could be a simple and cheap possible method (i.e. cell phone microphones hidden in barns at known coordinates) Alternatively: ISR drones, satellite ISR, RF triangulation, GPS transmitter on a fuze in an otherwise ‚Äòdumb‚Äô shell, luck‚Ä¶ or just local partisans.
@LoreyJeanene Perhaps, in this particular case, either might be appropriate‚Ä¶
@sroller @swavedave1 @Osinttechnical Those actually belong to the Army.

@glogeex @TrentTelenko @IntuitMachine 1. It may ‚Äòloiter‚Äô in level flight using the wing surfaces for lift (i.e. flying in circles vs. hovering); it may even try to take advantage of glider-like thermals 2. Those wings are likely semi-rigid shells covering a massive battery (e.g. flexible Li-Po cells) or fuel bladder

@SusanPotter @alyssa_holden_ @MayaGosztyla @markproxy Um, that‚Äôs an _amazingly_ useful overview. Thank you for sharing! (It seems sort of like the grandchild of a #KindleDX and a #PalmPilot that once saw an iPad, said ‚Äònope‚Äô, and moved to Maine.)

@ExpatInPL @WahlenPMattias @EydeDan @MarkHertling @jaketapper @ccn The radar will be a dozen meters or more above sea level, but yes, it‚Äôs not a tons of notice. Electronics work at nearly lightspeed, though‚Ä¶ if a point-defense system is active and properly manned, it should only take seconds for target lock and gun/interceptor firing.
